section.title: Demonstration 1 Main Page

content.text: This demonstration covers a more complex fixed asset referencing example. This is an example of a non-recurring purchase order (PJ) referencing two different personal property (ADMINEQUIP) asset records. Thus, two different assets are being purchased with the one purchase order. It demonstrates the following key concepts: How to reference multiple personal property fixed assets from a purchase order How to change asset accounting line amounts to ensure they total full amount of purchase order.
Demonstration 2 | Purchase Order with One Header Accounting Line to Multiple Asset Records
Pegasys Fixed Assets

content.text: In this demonstration, we will begin on the Header page
There is one Header Accounting Line on this PJ order. We will split the $200,000 into two Assets, and each Asset will have one Asset Accounting Line.
Click the Fixed Assets tab
The Fixed Assets page appears
Click the Add button so we can add the first Asset.
Enter the first Asset Number.
Enter the Asset Type for the first asset.
Enter the Betterment Number. It is 0, since this is a new asset.
Click the Accounting Lines tab.
We will create one Accounting Line for each Asset.
Click the Add button
The Accounting Line page appears
Both of these Accounting Lines will reference the only Header Accounting Line on this Order. So, we'll enter 1 in the Accounting Line Number field.
We will split the $200,000 on the Header Accounting Line between the two Assets. So we'll enter $100,000 on each Asset Accounting LIne.
Click the Fixed Assets link so we can add another asset.
The Fixed Assets page appears
Click the Add button
We'll enter the second Asset Number.
Then its Asset Type and Betterment Number.
Click the Accounting Lines tab, so we can add one for this asset.
Click the Add button
We're referencing the same Header Accounting Line so Accounting Line Number will be 1 again.
The Amount for this Accounting Line will be $100,000 too.
Click the Fixed Asset link
That's it. We have two Assets. Each has one Accounting Line and each Accounting Line references the one Header Accounting Line.
